full_text: Screened by NARA, 9/27/2023 INOVA FAIR OAKS HOSPITAL CONSULTATION PATIENT NAME: Sikri, Narain 3. HISTORY NUMBER: 1601822 DATE OF ADMISSION 8/5/97 DATE OF CONSULTATION: 8/8/97 ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: Anil Verma, M.D. CONSULTING PHYSICIAN: L. F. Smith, Jr., M.D. Mr. Sikri is a 93-year-old East Indian gentleman who was admitted with severe pain in the left leg and hip. He only has discomfort when he walks. There is no discomfort when he is lying or sitting. He points to the left hip joint posteriorly as the site of most of his pain. This has been present for about three weeks. A bone scan was carried out and revealed a lesion in the upper 1/3 of the femur on the left. The left hip joint and the remainder of the bone scan appears to be normal. He also has a normal alkaline phosphatase. His PSA is elevated at 6.7. Albumin is slightly depressed at 3.5 and he is slightly anemic, with a hemoglobin of 12.5, hematocrit 36, platelet count is 132,000, white count 16,400, 25 granulocytes, 69 lymphocytes. On the manual diff it was 26 segs, 71 lymphocytes. MEDICATIONS: The patient has been taking Roxicet for his pain He also takes Cardura. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Hypertension, osteoporosis, kyphosis and moderate hearing loss. SOCIAL HISTORY: He does not drink, he does not smoke. FAMILY HISTORY: His wife is deceased. He lives with his son. Family history otherwise is unknown. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: The only thing he complains about is the pain in his left hip. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Well-developed, quiet well-preserved gentleman for age 93. He is very hard of hearing. Skin: He has definite pallor to his skin. Mucous membranes are slightly pale. I do not feel any nodes in the cervical or axillary or inguinal region. His breath sounds are of good quality. His heart is irregular, no S3. Abdomen is soft. I do not feel the liver or spleen. Bowel sounds are normal. Rectal exam: His prostate is really not that large. He has a very firm right lobe, in fact a hard nodule in the right lobe of the prostate which occupies at least half of the right lobe. He has no peripheral edema. He has no significant pain when I press over his left femur. (Continued)
